Slide 2 Implement Strategies to decrease agitation, wandering, sundowning, and eating problems in patients. Identify Options for keeping the cognitively impaired older adult safe. Differentiate characteristics of Delirium, dementia, and depression. Assist With assessment of cognitive changes in the older adult. Discuss Ggeneral principles of care for older adults with altered cognitive functioning. Changes in Cognitive Functioning Slide 3 Age-associated memory impairment • Modest decline in short-term memory • Slight and gradual decline in cognitive skills Elderly as capable of learning new things as younger people • But speed of processing information is slower Examples of Mental Changes Not Caused by Normal Aging Process Slide 4 Confusion Disorientation Inappropriate behavior Depression Inability to follow directions Behaviors Associated with Cognitive Disorders Slide 5 • Usually preceded by increasing irritability • Sudden explosive outburst • Loud talking • Pacing Agitation/hostility/paranoia • Self-protective response to • Confusion • Fear • Sensory loss Behavior may also occur • Engage in conversation • Maintain a safe distance • Maintain eye contact • Move other patients out of immediate area Interventions Major Declines in Cognitive Functioning from conditions such as: Slide 6 Dementia Metabolic disorders Stress, alcohol abuse Undesirable medication effects Vision or hearing impairments Copyright © 2018, 2014, 2009 by Saunders, an imprint of Elsevier Inc. Types of Cognitive Impairment Slide 11  Confusion  Delirium  Nocturnal Delirium- Sundowning  Dementia Confusion Slide 12 Difficulty • Remembering • Learning • Following directions • Communicating needs Can significantly influence • Patient’s dignity • Independence, personality • Support system May complicate • Diagnosis • Treatment Delirium • Result of an underlying • Biologic cause • Psychological stressor  Can Occur suddenly or long period  Left untreated, can lead to coma or death  https://www.youtube.com/watch? v=FstSYkold5c Slid e 13 This Photo by Unknown author is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND. Nocturnal Delirium- "Sundowning"  Appearance or increase of symptoms associated  Late afternoon  Early evening hours  Usually into the night  Nursing Interventions  Minimize nocturnal confusion  Use of a night-light  Placing the call bell within reach  Reducing stimulation in the environment  Moving the patient closer to the nurses’ station  Protective devices  Should be used as a last-resort measure  May add to anxiety Slide 14 Dementia Slide 15 Generally permanent condition Slow onset affects • Memory • Intellectual functioning • Ability to problem-solve Occurs with • Primarily seen in Alzheimer’s • Brain tumors • Serious medical or surgical disorders Copyright © 2018, 2014, 2009 by Saunders, an imprint of Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. Nursing Interventions for Cognitive Impairment Slide 16  Goal  Psychosocial Approaches Nursing Interventions Slide 17 • Produce a feeling of well-being Goal • Reality orientation • Validation therapy • Reminiscence • Remotivation therapy • Resocialization • Family Support Psychosocial approaches Reality Orientation  Orient  Time  Place  Person  Maintain  Consistent interaction  Maintain  Consistent schedule  Mealtimes  Activities of daily living  Encourage  Use of memory aids  Clocks  Newspapers  TV & radio  Calendars Slide 18 Validation therapy  Decrease stress  Promote self-esteem and communication  Use group support  Encourage respect for the feelings  Encourage activities  Singing favorite songs  Reminiscing  Sharing mementos/family photographs Slide 19 Reminiscence  Reexamine past to promote Socialization Mental stimulation Wrap up unresolved issues  Individual or group sharing of life experiences Slide 20 Remotivation Therapy  Stimulate senses  Provide new motivation  Introduce interactions of  Pictures  Plants  Animals  Sounds  music Slide 21 Resocialization Therapy  Encourage socialization patterns within a group  Assign socialization roles  Serving each other refreshments  Encourage group projects  Participation in games Slid e 22 Pharmacotherapy  May improve  Appetite and sleep habits  Enhance socialization  Increase energy levels  Tranquilizers  Chlorpromazine (Thorazine) or haloperidol (Haldol)  To manage anxiety, agitation, hostility, and paranoia  Antidepressants  Citalopram (Celexa) or duloxetine (Cymbalta)  May be used if depression coexists with dementia Slide 23 Family Support Slide 24 Families need • Social and emotional support Often experiences changes • Lifestyle • Privacy • Socialization Adjustment can be enhanced • Integrating family into the nursing care plan Financial problems and multiple role responsibilities • Add to the burden Families should be encouraged to consider • Adult daycare • Respite care Copyright © 2018, 2014, 2009 by Saunders, an imprint of Elsevier Inc. Alzheimer's Disease Slide 25  How common  Stages  Nursing Interventions Alzheimer’s Disease Slide 26 Most common form of dementia (70%) 4th leading cause of death in the elderly population Loss of neurons in the frontal and temporal lobes Unable to process and integrate new information as well as retrieve memory Stages of Alzheimer’s Disease Slide 27 • Mild short-term memory difficulties • Difficulty learning new things • Mild depression Early stage • Increased short- or long-term memory loss • Suspicion, agitation, hallucination • ADLs affected • Wanders • Incontinent Middle stage • Severe memory impairment • Difficulty swallowing • Impaired mobility • Deteriorating speech • Bedridden • Weight loss Late stage Nursing Intervention Slide 28 Treatment is primarily symptomatic • Tacrine (Cognex) • Donepezil (Aricept) • Galantamine (Reminyl) • Rivastigmine (Exelon) • Work by increasing acetylcholine in the cerebral cortex Cholinesterase inhibitor drugs • Indomethacin (Indocin), estrogen, vitamin E, folic acid, possibly cholesterol-lowering drugs Other useful medications Copyright © 2018, 2014, 2009 by Saunders, an imprint of Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. Safety for Cognitive Impaired Slide 29  Mild Impairment  Increased Impairment Safety for the Cognitively Impaired Slide 30 Increasing impairment Alerting systems attached to outside doors Identification should be sewn into clothes and placed in wallet or purse Measures to alert the household if the person leaves the bedroom area at night Residential placement may needed Driving may become another safety issue Mild impairment Patient may be able to stay in own home safely Copyright © 2018, 2014, 2009 by Saunders, an imprint of Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. Challenges in Cognitive Impaired Slide 31  Wandering  Eating  Depression  Suicide  Alcohol Wandering  Tend to be very active people prior to the onset of disease  May be from boredom or restlessness  Nursing interventions  Identification bracelet that alarms with outside door  Ensuring environment is safe  Informing others about those that wander Slide 32 Eating Problems  Challenges  Lack of appetite  Refusal to open the mouth  Holding food in the mouth  Refusal to swallow food  Choking when swallowing Slide 33 Depression/Suicide/Alcohol Slide 34 • Result from multiple losses • Undiagnosed and untreated • Depression is a major contributor to alcoholism and suicide in the elderly! Depression • If older adult is experiencing suicidal thoughts... • They are more likely to act on them successfully! Suicide • Can interfere with management of chronic diseases Alcohol Nursing Interventions  Antidepressants  Tricyclics  Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)  Outpatient counseling or immediate crisis intervention Slide 35 This Photo by Unknown author is licensed under CC BY.
